head(Boston)

# Exercise 1

Use a for loop to simulate flipping a coin 10 times.

```{r}

for(i in 1:10){
  coin_side <- runif(1)
  if(coin_side > 0.5){
    print("Heads")
  } else {
    print("Tails")
  }
}
```

# Exercise 2

Compute the standard deviation of each column of Boston.

```{r}
# One way to do it
apply(Boston, MARGIN = 2, FUN = sd)
```

```{r}
# manual way to do it
standard_dev <- c()
for(i in 1:ncol(Boston)){
  standard_dev[i] <- sd(Boston[,i])
}
names(standard_dev) <- names(Boston)
standard_dev
```

# Exercise 3

Write an R function called flip_coin(), which has one argument called n that specifies the number of flips. Set the default n=1. Hereâ€™s an example of what the output of your function should look like:

```{r}
flip_coin <- function(n = 1){
  for(i in 1:n){
    coin_side <- runif(1)
    if(coin_side > 0.5){
      print("Heads")
    } else {
      print("Tails")
    }
  }
}
```

```{r}
flip_coin(5)
```
